io.zbox.zboxfs

Class File

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.zbox.zboxfs.File
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable

    public class File
extends Object
    A reference to an opened file in the repository.

    An instance of a File can be read and/or written depending on what options it was opened with. File also implements SeekFrom to alter the logical cursor that the file contains internally.

    Examples

    Create a new file and write bytes to it:

     File file = repo.createFile("/foo.txt");
 file.write("Hello, world!".getBytes());
 file.finish();
 file.close();

    Read the content of a file into a ByteBuffer:

     File file = repo.openFile("/foo.txt");
 ByteBuffer dst = file.readAll();
 file.close();

    Versioning

    File contents support up to 255 revision versions. Version is immutable once it is created.

    By default, the maximum number of versions of a File is 1, which is configurable by version_limit on both Repo and File level. File level option takes precedence.

    After reaching this limit, the oldest Version will be automatically deleted after adding a new one.

    Version number starts from 1 and continuously increases by 1.

    Writing

    File is multi-versioned, each time updating its content will create a new permanent Version. There are two ways of writing data to a file:

    • Multi-part Write

      This is done by updating File using write(byte[]) method multiple times. After all writing operations, finish() must be called to create a new Version.

      Examples
        File file = new OpenOptions().create(true).open(repo, "/foo.txt");
  long written = file.write("My text".getBytes());
  written = file.write("My text2".getBytes());
  file.finish();

    • Single-part Write

      This can be done by calling writeOnce(ByteBuffer), which will call finish() internally to create a new Version.

      Examples
        File file = new OpenOptions().create(true).open(repo, "/foo.txt");
  file.writeOnce("My text".getBytes());

    Reading

    As File can contain multiple versions, read operation can be associated with different versions. By default, reading on File object is always bound to the latest version. To read a specific version, a VersionReader, which supports VersionReader.read(byte[]) as well, can be used.

    Examples

    Read the file content while it is in writing, notice that reading is always bound to latest content version.

     byte[] buf = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6};
 byte[] buf2 = {7, 8};

 // create a file and write data to it
 File file = new OpenOptions().create(true).open(repo, "/foo.txt");
 file.writeOnce(buf);

 // read the first 2 bytes
 byte[] dst = new byte[2];
 file.seek(0, SeekFrom.START);
 file.read(dst);  // dst: [1, 2]

 // create a new version, now the file content is [1, 2, 7, 8, 5, 6]
 file.writeOnce(buf2);

 // notice that reading is on the latest version
 file.seek(-2, SeekFrom.CURRENT);
 file.read(dst);  // dst: [7, 8]

 fie.close();

    Read multiple versions using VersionReader.

     // create a file and write 2 versions
 File file = new OpenOptions().create(true).versionLimit(4).open(repo, "/foo.txt");
 file.writeOnce("foo".getBytes());
 file.writeOnce("bar".getBytes());

 // get latest version number
 long currVersion = file.currVersion();

 // create a version reader and read latest version of content
 VersionReader vr = file.versionReader(currVersion);
 ByteBuffer buf = vr.readAll();  // buf: "foobar"
 vr.close();

 // create another version reader and read previous version of content
 vr = file.versionReader(currVersion - 1);
 buf = vr.readAll();  // buf: "foo"
 vr.close();

 fie.close();
    See Also:
    Repo, OpenOptions

      • versionReader

        public VersionReader versionReader(long verNum)
                            throws ZboxException
        Get a reader of the specified version.

        The returned reader is a VersionReader. To get the version number, first call history() to get the list of all versions and then choose the version number from it.

        Parameters:
        verNum - version number
        Returns:
        a version reader
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

      • setLen

        public void setLen(long len)
            throws ZboxException
        Truncates or extends the underlying file, create a new version of content which size to become size.

        If the size is less than the current content size, then the new content will be shrunk. If it is greater than the current content size, then the content will be extended to size and have all of the intermediate data filled in with 0s.

        Parameters:
        len - the new length to be set
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

      • read

        public long read(ByteBuffer dst)
          throws ZboxException
        Pull all bytes from this file into the specified byte buffer, returning how many bytes were read.

        The bytes are appended to the destination buffer dst. That is, the writing starts from the current position in dst.

        It is recommended to use a direct ByteBuffer to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        dst - the byte buffer into which bytes are to be written
        Returns:
        number of bytes were read
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened
        See Also:
        read(OutputStream), readAll()

      • read

        public int read(byte[] dst,
                int off,
                int len)
         throws ZboxException
        Pull some bytes from this file into the specified byte array, returning how many bytes were read.

        This method copies n bytes from this file into the given destination array. If there is no exception thrown, then it must be guaranteed that 0 <= n <= len.

        It is recommended to make len less than 8KB (8192) to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        dst - the array into which bytes are to be written
        off - the offset within the array of the first byte to be written; must be non-negative and no larger than dst.length
        len - the maximum number of bytes to be written to the given array; must be non-negative and no larger than dst.length - offset
        Returns:
        number of bytes were read
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

      • read

        public int read(byte[] dst)
         throws ZboxException
        Pull some bytes from this file into the specified byte array, returning how many bytes were read.

        This method copies bytes from this file into the given destination array. An invocation of this method of the form file.read(dst) behaves in exactly the same way as the invocation

         file.read(dst, 0, dst.length)

        It is recommended to make dst.length less than 8KB (8192) to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        dst - the array into which bytes are to be written
        Returns:
        number of bytes were read
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

        Returns:

      • write

        public int write(byte[] src,
                 int off,
                 int len)
          throws ZboxException
        Write some bytes from the specified byte array into this file, returning how many bytes were written.

        This method copies n bytes from the given source array into this file. If there is no exception thrown, then it must be guaranteed that 0 <= n <= len.

        It is recommended to make len less than 8KB (8192) to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        src - the source array from which bytes are to be read
        off - the offset within the array of the first byte to be read; must be non-negative and no larger than dst.length
        len - the maximum number of bytes to be read from the given array; must be non-negative and no larger than dst.length - offset
        Returns:
        number of bytes were written
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

      • write

        public int write(byte[] src)
          throws ZboxException
        Write some bytes from the specified byte array into this file, returning how many bytes were written.

        This method copies bytes from the given source array into this file. An invocation of this method of the form file.write(dst) behaves in exactly the same way as the invocation

         file.write(src, 0, src.length)

        It is recommended to make src.length less than 8KB (8192) to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        src - the source array from which bytes are to be read
        Returns:
        number of bytes were written
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened

      • writeOnce

        public void writeOnce(ByteBuffer buf)
               throws ZboxException
        Single-part write to file and create a new version.

        This method provides a convenient way to combine write(byte[]) and finish().

        It is recommended to use a direct ByteBuffer to avoid extra memory allocation.

        Parameters:
        buf - the source byte buffer from which bytes are to be read
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened
        See Also:
        write(ByteBuffer), writeOnce(byte[]), writeOnce(InputStream)

      • writeOnce

        Parameters:

        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened
        See Also:
        write(byte[]), writeOnce(ByteBuffer), writeOnce(InputStream)

      • writeOnce

        Throws:

      • seek

        public long seek(long off,
                 SeekFrom whence)
          throws ZboxException
        Seek to an offset, relative to from in bytes, in this file.

        This method returns the new position from the start of the content. That position can be used later with SeekFrom.START.

        A seek beyond the end of the file is allowed. In this case, subsequent write will extend the file and have all of the intermediate data filled in with 0s.

        Parameters:
        off - the offset within this file, relative to whence
        whence - the start point to calculate seek offset
        Returns:
        new position from the start of the content
        Throws:
        ZboxException - if any error happened
        See Also:
        SeekFrom

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes this instance and releases any resources associated with this instance.

        Check if this instance has been closed.

        true if this instance is closed, otherwise false
